content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Find the lowest fare from all eligible one-way flights for 1 adult from JFK to Heathrow on May 22, 2026.  Please interact with https://www.google.com/travel/flights/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The initial flight search form is visible. To search for flights from JFK to Heathrow, I need to update the "Where from?" and "Where to?" fields. The field for the origin airport ("Where from?") currently says "Toronto", so I need to change it to "JFK" first.
Action: Type [13]; JFK
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Where from?" field is now set to "New York JFK". The next step is to enter the destination, which is Heathrow, in the "Where to?" field.
Action: Type [14]; Heathrow
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The departure ("New York JFK") and destination ("London LHR") fields are now set correctly. The next step is to select the departure date, which should be May 22, 2026.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently showing dates for September and October, but the required date is May 22, 2026. I need to move several months ahead to reach May 2026 by clicking the "Next" button.
Action: Click [74]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is still in late 2025. I need to reach May 2026, which requires clicking "Next" ([75]) several more times.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now shows November and December, but the target date is May 22, 2026. I need to continue clicking the "Next" button ([75]) to get to May 2026.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now shows January 2026, but the target date is May 22, 2026. I need to continue clicking the "Next" button ([76]) several more times to reach May.
Action: Click [76]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now shows February 2026, but the target date is May 22, 2026. I need to keep clicking the "Next" button ([73]) to reach May.
Action: Click [73]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.55
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now shows March 2026. To reach May 22, 2026, I need to continue clicking the "Next" button ([73]) to advance more months.
Action: Click [73]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now shows April 2026, but I need to reach May 22, 2026. I need to keep clicking the "Next" button ([75]) to move forward to May 2026.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.65
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now displays May 2026. May 22, 2026, is visible and marked with a price of $779. To select this date, I need to click on the element representing May 22.
Action: Click [72]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The selected departure date has changed to May 30, 2026, instead of the required May 22, 2026. I need to select May 22, 2026, again and then proceed by clicking "Done" to search for flights on that date.
Action: Click [67]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.85

Thought: The departure date is now set to May 22, 2026, which is the correct date for the task. To proceed with searching for eligible flights and viewing fares, I need to click the "Done" button to confirm the selection and move forward.
Action: Click [79]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.9

content.text:
Observation: please analyze the attached screenshot and give the Thought and Action. I've provided the tag name of each element and the text it contains (if text exists). Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.
[2]: <button> "Travel";	[3]: <button> "Explore";	[4]: <button> "Flights";	[5]: <button> "Hotels";	[6]: <button> "Vacation rentals";	[7]: <button> "Change appearance";	[9]: "Sign in";	[11]: <button> "1", "1 passenger";	[13]: <input> "Where from? New York JFK";	[14]: <button> "Swap origin and destination.";	[15]: <input> "Where to? London LHR";	[16]: <input> "Departure";	[17]: <button> "";	[18]: <button> "";	[19]: <input> "Return";	[20]: <button> "Search";	[21]: <button> "Explore deals";

content:
Thought: All flight search criteria are now set: one-way, 1 passenger, JFK to Heathrow, departing May 22, 2026. The next step is to initiate the search for eligible flights and fares by clicking the "Search" button.
Action: Click [20]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.95

Thought: The calendar view is showing the flight prices for May 2026, including May 22, which is highlighted with a fare of $778 CAD. This is the lowest fare visible for one-way flights from JFK to Heathrow on May 22, 2026.
Action: ANSWER; The lowest fare for a one-way flight from JFK to Heathrow for 1 adult on May 22, 2026, is $778 CAD.
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 1.0
token: : ANSWER; The lowest fare for a one-way flight from JFK to Heathrow for 1 adult on May 22, 2026, is $778 CAD
